description: 131gr projectile of a .223 OCG Blackout round removed from its casing. Cannot be put back. Perhaps may yet be useful.
An unfired, like-new .22 ETC round casing, with the plasma cartridge still intact.
100gr projectile of a .22 ETC TB round removed from its casing. Cannot be put back, perhaps may yet be useful.
9gr micro-flechette of a .22 ETC round removed from its plastic capsule. Cannot be put back and is too tiny for nail guns. Perhaps may yet be useful.
185gr projectile of a 5.56 ETC SAP round removed from its casing. Cannot be put back. Perhaps may yet be useful.
154gr projectile of a 5.56 OCG Noctis round removed from its casing. Cannot be put back. Perhaps may yet be useful.
40gr projectile of a 9mm ETC HAPM round removed from its casing. Cannot be put back or further disassembled. Perhaps may yet be useful.
262gr projectile of a 9mm ETC SAP round removed from its casing. Cannot be put back. Perhaps may yet be useful.
Plasma cartridge from a small electrothermal-chemical pistol round.
Plasma cartridge from a small electrothermal-chemical rifle round.
Plasma cartridge from a large electrothermal-chemical rifle round.

A liquid core reactor with milliseconds of operational lifetime that fits inside a large rifle round case, it can discharge enough power for one shot in an electrothermal-chemical weapon. While this means every time a 7.62mm EC gun fires a bullet a nuclear reactor goes supercritical, due to its extremely short lifespan and tiny size, the radiation is so insignificant millions of bullets would have to be fired before anything could be detected by the average geiger counter. This is a sliver of next generation atomic space propulsion and powerplant tech which will never be applied in space now.

A fractioned and "reassembled" liquid core reactor with milliseconds of operational lifetime that fits inside a large rifle round case for UPS-free electrothermal operation. Unshielded liquid core reactors like this one were once considered, in a much larger scale, for nuclear thermal space propulsion in unmanned spacecrafts despite extreme radiation leaks because in spaceflight every gram counts. While this is smaller than any nuclear rocket engine by orders of magnitude, it is very dangerous too: the product of either a genius or insane survivor atomic scientist, but not both; radiation poisoning will likely doom its maker

A tiny dose of highly radioactive slurry from a nanoreactor, essentially a fraction of its liquid core without any shielding, which could be used to craft a self-charged 7.62mm electrothermal-chemical round or even a radioactive dirty bomb. There is no way to craft something handmade in such small scale with proper radiation shielding. Maybe you should give up and get far away from this instead.
